Dear Christy Shillings:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Cassandra Thomas, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to: (ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth has gone AWOL multiple times. Recently, youth's face and
eye were swollen. Youth had bruising on the face and around the
eye. In the past, youth sustained a black eye. Youth reports that
the staff are mean and put their hands on him in ways they should
not.
Investigation Interviews:
On 08/02/2024 an email was sent to Foster Care Worker
advising of investigation involving Youth A and inquiring about any
concerns with the agency. On 08/13/2024 an email response was
received from the Foster Care Worker. She replied that she
spoke with Youth A on the phone on 8/6/2024 and reviewed the
safety concerns with him. She reported seeing him in person on
8/7/2024 and he did not report any injuries or bruises. He did
have some bites that she stated looked like bed bug bites on him,
and she advised the agency of the concern. She reported her plan
to see him again on 8/17/24. Foster Care Worker reported that
Youth A stated he has made some “friends” in the local area and
that he is going to continue to go AWOL and do what he wants to
do. No other concerns were reported.
Complainant was called on the telephone on 08/07/2024 with no
answer. There was no voicemail to leave a message.
All of the following interviews took place on 08/07/2024 at
Wolverine along with DHHS Specialist, unless otherwise
noted.
An onsite visit was completed to Wolverine. Chief Administrator
was advised of the investigation and informed of the allegations.
She confirmed that Youth A is currently on one-to-one staffing but
continues to AWOL. She reported staff makes attempts to deter
2

him from going AWOL without success and he goes AWOL
frequently. The deterrence includes talking with him about the
dangers of the community, trying to redirect his attention to other
things and even offering a reward is he refrains from going AWOL
for the day. A request was made for incident reports involving
Youth A, they were provided and outlined below. Chief
Administrator denied that staff has been “hitting or pinching” Youth
A. She also denied that Youth A had bruises or a swollen face.
She was advised that Youth A reported that Staff 3 “pinched or
grabbed” him. She denied knowledge of any restraints or
incidents that would result in bruising. She further reported that
staff have been monitoring and documenting all behavior
associated with Youth A. Chief Administrator reported that she
had been expecting a visit from DHHS as they received a call from
the mother of Youth A on 7/21/24 stating that Youth A had a
bruise on his face. When Youth A returned from AWOL status no
one noticed any injuries, bruising or marks on him. She further
reported that Youth A went for a medical on 7/22/2024. DHHS
specialist developed a safety plan with Chief Administrator. It was
requested that all staff follow Wolverine policies and procedures
especially regarding proper physical interactions with youth and
AWOL response. It was also advised staff document all physical
restraints and redirections for Youth A due to his limited capacity
to verbalize things that have occurred.
Youth A was interviewed and reported that he had been being
“good”. He denied having any bruises, marks or injuries but
confirmed having a couple of scrapes from the slide. Youth A
denied having any injuries since being placed at the facility in
June. He also denied that there has been a time when staff has
been physically inappropriate with him. He further stated he has
never been pinched, pulled or kicked by Wolverine Staff. He
denied ever being hurt by the staff at Wolverine. Youth A also
reported that he has been in a fight with a youth and staff
intervened and broke it up. He denied being hurt by staff when
they broke up the fight. Youth A reported that the bruise on his
side was from a youth pinching him but could not recall the name
of the youth.
Youth A further reported that Staff 3 talks mean to him. When
asked for an example, he stated that Staff 3 tells him to be quiet
and tells other staff not to talk to him. He also confirmed that he
goes AWOL a lot but stated that staff talks to him about it and
asks him to “please don’t” go AWOL. He reported that he went
AWOL last night and went to the store to get snacks with the
money he made. He declined to share how he made the money.
3

Youth A then stated that he had bruising on his face that his
mother saw but reported that it was done by “kids here”. He was
unable to recall or provide names of the “kids” that caused the
bruising to his face.
Youth B was interviewed and denied that he has ever seen a staff
hit, punch or be inappropriate with youth.
Youth C was interviewed and reported that he gets along with the
staff at Wolverine. He denied seeing staff be physically
inappropriate with youth and has never been injured himself by
staff. He further denied seeing staff be physically or verbally
inappropriate with Youth A. He referred to Youth A as a liar and
stated that he often says things that are not true. He confirmed
that staff will try to deter youth from going AWOL and that staff
request youth to go for a medical exam when they return from
AWOL status.
Lead Supervisor was interviewed and denied seeing Youth A
with any bruises or injuries to his face or other area of his body.
She also denied that seeing or having knowledge of any staff
being physically inappropriate with Youth A or any youth in the
program. She did report that she has seen Youth A hit staff with
sticks, spit on staff and tell untruths.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed and denied seeing Youth A with a
bruise to his face or a black or swollen eye. He does not recall the
specific night when he returned on 7/21/2024 or 7/22/2024. He
reports that he is frequently attempting to deter youth from going
AWOL and advising of the danger associated with it.
All of the following interviews took place on 09/19/2024 at
Wolverine unless otherwise noted.
Youth D and Youth E were interviewed and confirmed that youth
do fight with each other and staff stop it and separate the youth.
They denied seeing or having knowledge of staff injuring youth at
the facility.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed, and both denied physically
or verbally attacking youth at the facility and denied seeing other
staff do so.
Documents Reviewed:
DHHS Specialist Social Work Contacts:
4

On 08/02/2024 Youth A was interviewed by DHHS Specialist at
Wolverine. This information was obtained from review of the
social work contact completed by DHHS Specialist. Youth A
reported he goes AWOL because “kids and staff pinch me” and
lifted his shirt to show his chest and stomach. A picture of the
area was taken by DHHS specialist and described as multiple red
bumps on his stomach resembling eczema or similar skin
condition and a round bruise on his upper right rib cage/abdomen.
Youth A reported the bruise came from “staff”. Initially he reported
that he did not remember what staff pinched him, but then
reported “Staff 3” grabbed him. He was asked if he had been
restrained when that occurred, and he reported he did not
remember. He was asked if the staff was attempting to move him
when he thought he was grabbed and he reported he didn't
remember. Youth A also indicated that he did not recall if it was
intentional or an accident. Youth A was not able to recall or
verbalize when this “injury” occurred, what staff was present or
what the circumstances were. Youth A confirmed that he goes
AWOL and reported that he usually goes to the Dollar Store and
denied going anywhere else. He reported that he had a bruised
eye from an incident with another youth punching him a few
weeks ago. He reported he called his mother via Facetime when
he was AWOL, and she took pictures of his bruised eye. Youth A
was not able to provide specifics surrounding when or where it
occurred or what youth were involved. Youth A then asked the
DHHS Specialist for the interview to end.
On 08/21/2024 a telephone call was made to Complainant by
DHHS Specialist. This information was obtained from review of
the social work contact completed by DHHS Specialist. She
advised that she does have concerns with Wolverine. She
reported that Youth A goes AWOL all of the time and she believes
that he is getting into drugs during that time. She advised that she
believes that he is getting hurt when he leaves Wolverine and is in
the community. She also reported that Youth A told her that he is
being restrained in ways that he should not when he is at the
facility. Lastly Complainant stated that Youth A has never
indicated any specific names or staff at Wolverine who he had
concerns with.
On 08/21/2024 an email correspondence was received from
Therapist 1 by DHHS Specialist. This information was obtained
from review of the social work contact completed by DHHS
Specialist. He noted “no concerns at this time”. He advised that
Youth A told him that one of his peers told him that if staff ever
tried to physically manage him to put his hands in his pants and
5

when staff would remove his hands from his pants to initiate CPI,
tell DHHS that he was sexually assaulted by staff. Therapist 1
reported he informed Youth A that this was inappropriate advice.
On 08/26/2024 DHHS specialist spoke with Social Worker 1 of
Children’s Hospital. This information was obtained from review of
the social work contact completed by DHHS Specialist. It was
confirmed that he was seen for a medical exam on 7/26/2024.
She advised that there were no marks, bruises or injuries noted on
Youth A and that he denied being abused at Wolverine or when
he left the facility.
On 08/27/2024 a DHHS Closing Case Conference was held.
DHHS Specialist, Foster Care Worker and DCWL Area Manager
participated. It was noted that there were no findings of abuse
and neglect and no preliminary findings of non-compliance with
licensing rules.
On 08/28/2024 DHHS specialist spoke with Social Worker 2 of
St. John’s. This information was obtained from review of the
social work contact completed by DHHS Specialist. Social Worker
advised that Youth A was seen on August 3rd due to leaving the
facility and not returning for several hours. She reported that he
denied any substance use while he was away from the facility and
there were no signs of use. DHHS Specialist was informed that
the doctors did examine Youth A and there was no noted abuse or
neglect concerns.
On 08/28/2024 DHHS Specialist completed an interview with Staff
3 via telephone. This information was obtained from review of the
social work contact completed by DHHS Specialist. Staff 3
confirmed that he was familiar with Youth A and worked with him
quite often. He denied that he has ever pinched or grabbed Youth
A and he has never physically hurt him. He denied recalling a time
when Youth A had bruising on his face.
Wolverine AWOL Policy: Staff will make efforts to verbally
redirect the truanting youth and will offer the youth support and
alternatives to truancy. If a non-supervising staff is available, they
will walk with the youth and continue to provide verbal support and
redirection encouraging the youth not to truant.
Staff will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist Supervisor
on duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 minutes from
loss of line of sight (when youth is determined AWOL). The Youth
Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead Supervisor and
6

Program Management who will provide oversight for incident
management. The youth specialist supervisor will ensure law
enforcement is notified immediately (no more than 5 minutes from
when youth is determined AWOL). Staff will notify law
enforcement and program director. Client specifics will be
provided to Law enforcement and an IR will be completed.
When a Client Returns:
If the client returns to the site, the appropriate supervising agency
must be contacted for authorization to re-admit the client and
remove the client’s truancy status. All parties notified of truancy
must also be notified at the time of return.
Incident Reports involving Youth A: Incidents reports were
received involving Youth A. There were a total of 21 incident
reports between 07/11/2024 and 08/06/2024 related to Youth A
going AWOL. Specifically, there were 2 reports for 07/21/2024 that
indicated Youth A was redirected from going AWOL at 8:34am.
The next IR documented that Youth A wanted to leave the
lunchroom and required additional redirection from staff. Youth A
remained escalated throughout the day. It documented that Youth
A was hit by another youth and continue to try and argue with the
youth during the day. The IR documents that Youth A sustained
no injuries from being hit and no physical management was
utilized. There is also an incident report from 07/22/2024 stating
that after breakfast Youth A said he was still hungry and went
AWOL advising he was going to get McDonalds. It was noted that
there were no injuries observed on Youth A and no physical
management was used. Review of all of the reports document that
no physical management was utilized with Youth A and no injuries
to his face were ever noted to be observed before or after going
AWOL. It should be noted that after every return from AWOL, the
youth is requested to go for a medical exam. Youth A usually
declined, but it was noted that he went for a medical exam on
7/26/24 and 8/02/2024 with no injuries or bruises being noted.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rules. Interviews were completed
with both staff and youth at the agency and there was no evidence
to support non-compliance with licensing rule 4158-1-a-ii. All
youth and staff interviewed denied seeing Youth A with bruising to
his face and denied that staff engage in inappropriate physical
activity with youth at the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

Rule Code Program Statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 109. (1) An institution shall have and follow a current
Section written program statement which specifically addresses all of the
Description following: (c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Additional Findings
Type
Allegation Agency staff did not provide proper protection to youth by failing to
allow him entry into building when he returned from AWOL status.
Investigation On 08/07/2024 an onsite visit was completed to Wolverine. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Chief Administrator was
advised of the investigation and informed of the allegations. She
confirmed that Youth A is currently on one-to-one staffing but
continues to AWOL. She reported staff makes attempts to deter
him from going AWOL without success and he goes AWOL
frequently. The deterrence includes talking with him about the
dangers of the community, trying to redirect his attention to other
things and even offering a reward is he refrains from going AWOL
for the day.
On 10/03/2024 an in-person interview was completed with Chief
Administrator. She confirmed that AWOL policy does not
specifically indicate that youth cannot enter with a mask on. She
indicated the agency considers the ski mask contraband. She
was asked if the youth was allowed to remain in the foyer area
until he would remove the mask, and she indicated that she
believed that to be a good plan of action but does not know if that
is what occurred in this incident.
On 10/14/2024 Chief Administrator confirmed via email that the
definition of contraband is not included in any of their policies.
She further advised that all staff and supervisors are aware that
when a client returns from AWOL with anything other than the
shoes and clothing provided by Wolverine Center, the client is not
allowed to return to their unit until the clients gives up those items.
On 08/07/2024 an in-person interview was completed with Youth
A. The DHHS specialist was also present. He reported that he
8

went AWOL and when he returned, Supervisor 2 refused to let
him in. He then went to a house on Dickerson, used someone’s
cell phone and called his mother. He reported that his mother
called Wolverine and told the staff that they had to let Youth A in.
On 08/07/2024 Youth B and Youth C were interviewed and DHHS
Specialist was present. They both denied having knowledge of
youth being refused entry to the building.
On 08/07/2024 Lead Supervisor was interviewed and DHHS
specialist was present. She denied knowledge of staff refusing
entry to youth after they return from being AWOL.
On 08/07/2024 Supervisor 2 was interviewed and DHHS specialist
was present. He denied knowledge of any staff refusing youth
entry into the building when returning from being AWOL.
Supervisor 2 recalled an instance when Youth A attempted to
return with a ski mask on, having his face covered, and he was
told that he could not enter with his face covered. Supervisor 2
reported that Youth A left and returned about 5 to 10 minutes later
without the mask and was allowed to come in. Staff was not able
to recall the exact date.
On 10/08/2024 a telephone call was made to Supervisor 2 to
further discuss the return of Youth A to the facility wearing a ski
mask. He confirmed that it was during the summer month and the
weather did not support wearing the mask. He reported that he
asked Youth A to remove the ski mask before entering and Youth
A refused. Supervisor 2 reported he then told Youth A that he
would not be able to enter until he removed the mask and Youth A
decided to turn around and leave. Supervisor 2 confirmed that
Youth A never made it into the building, and he did not consider
having him wait in the foyer area and continue efforts to get him to
remove the ski-mask.
All of the following interviews took place on 09/19/2024 at
Wolverine unless otherwise noted.
Youth D and Youth E were interviewed and denied knowledge of
staff refusing to allow staff back into the building after returning
from AWOL.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed, and both denied knowledge
of staff refusing to allow staff back into the building when they
return from being AWOL. Both denied ever personally not
allowing a youth to re-enter the building.
9

On 08/27/2024 a DHHS Closing Case Conference was held.
DHHS Specialist, Foster Care Worker and DCWL Area Manager
participated. It was noted that there were no findings of abuse
and neglect and no preliminary findings of non-compliance with
licensing rules.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine AWOL Policy: Staff will make efforts to verbally redirect
the truanting youth and will offer the youth support and
alternatives to truancy. If a non-supervising staff is available, they
will walk with the youth and continue to provide verbal support and
redirection encouraging the youth not to truant.
Staff will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist Supervisor
on duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 minutes from
loss of line of sight (when youth is determined AWOL). The Youth
Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead Supervisor and
Program Management who will provide oversight for incident
management. The youth specialist supervisor will ensure law
enforcement is notified immediately (no more than 5 minutes from
when youth is determined AWOL). Staff will notify law
enforcement and program director. Client specifics will be
provided to Law enforcement and an IR will be completed.
When a Client Returns:
If the client returns to the site, the appropriate supervising agency
must be contacted for authorization to re-admit the client and
remove the client’s truancy status. All parties notified of truancy
must also be notified at the time of return.
It was noted that the policy failed to reference or identify
“contraband” and the Chief Administrator confirmed that none of
the agency policies defined what is considered contraband.
Analysis The agency was found to be in non-compliance with the licensing
rule. The agency failed to ensure proper safety and protection of
the youth by failing to allow his entry into the facility when he
returned from AWOL status. It was reported that youth was
denied entry due to his possession of a ski-mask which was
assessed as “contraband”. After the review of the AWOL policy, it
failed to identify this process, and the agency does not have a
working definition of contraband in its policy and procedures that
would support the decision of the staff to not allow the youth entry
into the facility. Although several interviews of both staff and
youth denied knowledge of residents not being allowed entry after
10

being AWOL, the interview of Supervisor 2 confirmed failure to
allow Youth A entry when he returned from AWOL as it was
assessed that he possessed contraband.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules therefore, a corrective action plan is required.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted at the Wolverine Center following allegations that a youth (Youth A) was physically abused by staff and sustained bruises and a swollen face. The investigation, which included interviews and document reviews, found no evidence to substantiate the claims of physical punishment or improper intervention by staff. However, the investigation did confirm that the facility failed to ensure the youth's safety and protection when a supervisor denied him re-entry to the building after an AWOL incident because he was wearing a ski mask, which was deemed 'contraband' despite no policy defining that term. While the facility was cleared of the abuse allegations, the report places culpability for the safety violation squarely on the agency for its failure to have and follow clear policies regarding re-admission and contraband.
